contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox mineral | name = Lepidolite | category = [[Silicate mineral]] | boxwidth = | boxbgcolor = | image = Lepidolite-76774.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Lepidolite, [[Virgem da Lapa]], [[Minas Gerais]], Brazil (size 2.4 x 2.1 x 0.7 cm) | formula = K(Li,Al)<sub>3</sub>(Al,Si)<sub>4</sub>O<sub>10</sub>(F,OH)<sub>2</sub> | strunz = 09.EC.20 | symmetry = Monoclinic [[H-M symbol]]: 2/m <br/>[[Space group]]: C 2/m,Cm | unit cell = a = 5.209(2) [[angstrom|Å]] b = 9.011(5) Å <br/>c = 10.149(5) Å; <br/>β = 100:77(4)°; Z = 2 | molweight = | color = Pink, purple, rose-red, violet-gray, yellowish, white, colorless | habit = Tabular to prismatic pseudohexagonal crystals, scaly aggregates and massive | system = [[Monoclinic]] | twinning = Rare, composition plane {001} | cleavage = {001} perfect | fracture = Uneven | mohs = 2.5–3 | luster = Vitreous to pearly | polish = | refractive = n<sub>α</sub>=1.525–1.548, n<sub>β</sub>=1.551–1.58, n<sub>γ</sub>=1.554–1.586 | opticalprop = Biaxial (-) | birefringence = 0.0290–0.0380 | dispersion = | 2V = 0° - 58° measured | pleochroism = X = almost colorless; Y = Z = pink, pale violet | fluorescence= | absorption = | streak = White | gravity = 2.8–2.9 | density = | melt = | fusibility = | diagnostic = | solubility = | diaphaneity = Transparent to translucent | other = | references = <ref name=Handbook>[http://rruff.geo.arizona.edu/doclib/hom/lepidolite.pdf Handbook of Mineralogy]</ref><ref name=Webmin>[http://webmineral.com/data/Lepidolite.shtml Webmineral]</ref> }} '''Lepidolite''' is a lilac-gray or rose-colored member of the [[mica]] group with formula K(Li,Al)<sub>3</sub>(Al,Si)<sub>4</sub>O<sub>10</sub>(F,OH)<sub>2</sub>.<ref name=Handbook/><ref name=Webmin/> It is a secondary source of [[lithium]]. It is a [[silicate minerals|phyllosilicate]] [[mineral]]<ref>Hurlbut, Cornelius S.; Klein, Cornelis (1985), ''Manual of Mineralogy,'' Wiley, (20th ed.) ISBN 0-471-80580-7</ref> and a member of the polylithionite-trilithionite series.<ref>[http://www.mindat.org/min-2380.html Lepidolite on Mindat.org]</ref> It is associated with other lithium-bearing minerals like [[spodumene]] in [[pegmatite]] bodies. It is one of the major sources of the rare [[alkali metal]]s [[rubidium]] and [[caesium]].<ref>H. Nechamkin, ''The Chemistry of the Elements'', McGraw-Hill, New York, 1968.</ref> In 1861 [[Robert Bunsen]] and [[Gustav Kirchhoff]] extracted 150 kg of lepidolite and yielded a few grams of rubidium salts for analysis, and therefore discovered the new element rubidium.<ref>{{cite journal | title = Chemische Analyse durch Spectralbeobachtungen | pages = 337–381 | author = G. Kirchhoff, R. Bunsen | doi = 10.1002/andp.18611890702 | journal = [[Annalen der Physik und Chemie]] | volume = 189 | issue = 7 | year = 1861 | bibcode=1861AnP...189..337K}}</ref> It occurs in [[granite]] [[pegmatite]]s, in some high-temperature quartz veins, [[greisen]]s and granites. Associated minerals include [[quartz]], [[feldspar]], [[spodumene]], [[amblygonite]], [[tourmaline]], [[columbite]], [[cassiterite]], [[topaz]] and [[beryl]].<ref name=Handbook/> Notable occurrences include [[Brazil]]; [[Ural Mountains]], [[Russia]]; [[California]], [[United States]]; [[Tanco Mine]], [[Bernic Lake]], [[Manitoba]], [[Canada]]; and [[Madagascar]]. <gallery widths="200px" heights="200px" perrow="2"> File:Lepidolite-140533.jpg|Yellow lepidolite from [[Itinga]], [[Minas Gerais]], Brazil.
